xxl.core.util.metaData
Class TransparentCompositeMetaData<I,M>

java.lang.Object
  xxl.core.util.metaData.CompositeMetaData<I,M>
      xxl.core.util.metaData.TransparentCompositeMetaData<I,M>
Type Parameters:
I - the type of the identifiers.
M - the type of the metadata fragments.
All Implemented Interfaces:
java.io.Serializable, java.lang.Cloneable, java.lang.Iterable<java.util.Map.Entry<I,M>>
public class TransparentCompositeMetaData<I,M>
extends CompositeMetaData<I,M>

A composite metadata object that wraps another one in a transparent way. The metadata fragments of the wrapped composite metadata are fully visible from the transparent composite metadata object, but changes to the transparent composite metadata's fragment will only be done locally. I. e., new metadata fragments will be added/put/replaced/removed in the transparent composite metadata while the the wrapped composite metadata stays unchanged.

Imagine the following situation. The transparent composite metadata T has locally stored the following IDs and fragments T {id1 frag1, id2 frag2} and wraps a composite metadata C that stores the following IDs and fragments C {id2 frag2, id3 frag3}. Then T will globally look like this T {id1 frag1, id2 frag2, id3 frag3} and the following calls will produce the listed results.

call result reason/effect
T.add(id1, frag) MetaDataException T already contains id1
T.add(id2, frag) MetaDataException T already contains id2
T.add(id3, frag) MetaDataException C already contains id3
T.add(id4, frag) id4 frag is inserted into T
T.put(id1, frag) frag1 id1 frag1 is replaced by id1 frag in T
T.put(id2, frag) frag2 id2 frag2 is replaced by id2 frag in T
T.put(id3, frag) frag3 id3 frag is inserted into T (and hides id3 frag3 from C)
T.put(id4, frag) null id3 frag is inserted into T
T.replace(id1, frag) frag1 id1 frag1 is replaced by id1 frag in T
T.replace(id2, frag) frag2 id2 frag2 is replaced by id2 frag in T
T.replace(id3, frag) frag3 id3 frag is inserted into T (and hides id3 frag3 from C)
T.replace(id4, frag) MetaDataException T and C do not contain id4
T.contains(id1) true T contains id1
T.contains(id2) true T contains id2
T.contains(id3) true C contains id3
T.contains(id4) false T and C do not contain id4
T.get(id1) frag1 T contains id1
T.get(id2) frag2 T contains id2
T.get(id3) frag3 C contains id3
T.get(id4) MetaDataException T and C do not contain id4
T.remove(id1) frag1 id1 frag1 is removed from T
T.remove(id2) frag2 id2 frag2 is removed from T (but still visible from C)
T.remove(id3) MetaDataException C cannot be changed
T.remove(id4) MetaDataException T and C do not contain id4

Note, the above-mentioned behaviour shows differences between composite metadata and transparent composite metadata. First, when the transparent composite metadata as well as the wrapped composite metadata contains the same ID then the removal of it will return the removed fragment but the ID stays in the transparent composite metadata (because it is also part of the wrapped composite metadata). Second, when an ID is only part of the wrapped composite metadata but not of the surrounding transparent composite metadata then the removal of it will be impossible.

See Also:
MetaDataProvider.getMetaData(), MetaDataException, Serialized Form

Creates a new transparent composite metadata that wraps the given composite metadata. The wrapped composite metadata's fragments are made visible from the surrounding transparent composite metadata, but cannot be changed.

get

public M get(I identifier)
      throws MetaDataException
Returns the metadata fragment the specified identifier is associated with by this composite metadata. A return value of null indicates that null is explicitly associated with the given identifier by the composite metadata. If the composite metadata does not contain a metadata fragment for the specified identifier, an exception is thrown.

hashCode

public int hashCode()
Returns the hash code value for this composite metadata. The hash code of a composite metadata is defined to be the sum of the hash codes of each stored metadata fragment. This ensures that t1.equals(t2) implies that t1.hashCode()==t2.hashCode() for any two composite metadata objects t1 and t2, as required by the general contract of Object.hashCode.

This implementation simply returns the hash code of the internally used hash map.

Overrides:
hashCode in class CompositeMetaData<I,M>
Returns:
the hash code value for this composite metadata.
See Also:
Object.hashCode(), equals(Object)

equals

public boolean equals(java.lang.Object object)
Indicates whether some other object is "equal to" this composite metadata.

The equals method implements an equivalence relation:

  • It is reflexive: for any reference value x, x.equals(x) should return true.
  • It is symmetric: for any reference values x and y, x.equals(y) should return true if and only if y.equals(x) returns true.
  • It is transitive: for any reference values x, y, and z, if x.equals(y) returns true and y.equals(z) returns true, then x.equals(z) should return true.
  • It is consistent: for any reference values x and y, multiple invocations of x.equals(y) consistently return true or consistently return false, provided no information used in equals comparisons on the object is modified.
  • For any non-null reference value x, x.equals(null) should return false.

The current equals method returns true if and only if the given object:

  • is this composite metadata or
  • is an instance of the type CompositeMetaData and the internally used hash maps of this and the specified object are equal.

Overrides:
equals in class CompositeMetaData<I,M>
Parameters:
object - the reference object with which to compare.
Returns:
true if this object is the same as the specified object; false otherwise.
See Also:
hashCode()

toString

public java.lang.String toString()
Returns a string representation of the composite metadata. In general, the toString method returns a string that "textually represents" this object. The result should be a concise but informative representation that is easy for a person to read.

The toString method for this class simply returns the textually representation of its internally user hash map.
